title: Compressing callstacks: a bitpacked DAG powered by a keyless hashmap
I wish I could hide ATProto discussion on here
description:
I've seen the discussion at https://lobste.rs/s/4ixrx6/tag_proposal_atproto, so I'm acutely aware that this is not going to get a tag, but I also don't know what else to do but write about my feelings.

Considering the risks of delving deeply into the nitty protocol discussions, I want to apply a razor here, I feel like most of the social capital of ATProto comes from Bluesky (read: you can capture Bluesky's users / infrastructure (or you already are a user) per the shared protocol).

I'm uncertain how that pans out when Bluesky goes away. If my understanding is correct, hosting your own PDS allows you to go to another network if Bluesky goes hostile since your data is on your machine. I don't know if another network would gain much traction, let alone if most people (have the skills to migrate and / or) host their own PDS, compared to using Bluesky wholly like any regular centralized app.

I remember someone made counter that showed the percentage of selfhosted PDSs, but I don't remember the domain anymore.

So, I'm pessimistic about the future of ATProto, which makes these two recent stories stand out to me:

  • https://lobste.rs/s/jxubs2/internet_handle
  • https://lobste.rs/s/yh2bjm/open_social

These stories aren't easy to single out as ATProto articles, and make bold (ideological?) claims about the potential future implications of the protocol. I don't have ill will against the submitter or the author, they're just the easiest and starkest examples, I wish them luck with this herculean task.

I don't want to impose my opinion as correct opinion, quite the opposite, I want to leave others to experiment and have fun, I want these stories to be on here.

I'm happy that there's so much interest in the protocol, because it could work out if enough people build on top of it to make sure it's actually an open protocol and not just the Bluesky and friends protocol.

But until the dust settles, I wish I could just tune it out on here because these stories are really frustrating to me as a reader, and I don't know how I can hide them (compared to things like vibecoding / ai).

I hope my sob story isn't too disruptive, I don't think I've seen this kind of text written on here before.
description_plain:
I've seen the discussion at https://lobste.rs/s/4ixrx6/tag_proposal_atproto, so I'm acutely aware that this is not going to get a tag, but I also don't know what else to do but write about my feelings.

Considering the risks of delving deeply into the nitty protocol discussions, I want to apply a razor here, I feel like most of the social capital of ATProto comes from Bluesky (read: you can capture Bluesky's users / infrastructure (or you already are a user) per the shared protocol).

I'm uncertain how that pans out when Bluesky goes away. If my understanding is correct, hosting your own PDS allows you to go to another network if Bluesky goes hostile since your data is on your machine. I don't know if another network would gain much traction, let alone if most people (have the skills to migrate and / or) host their own PDS, compared to using Bluesky wholly like any regular centralized app.

I remember someone made counter that showed the percentage of selfhosted PDSs, but I don't remember the domain anymore.

So, I'm pessimistic about the future of ATProto, which makes these two recent stories stand out to me:
- https://lobste.rs/s/jxubs2/internet_handle
- https://lobste.rs/s/yh2bjm/open_social

These stories aren't easy to single out as ATProto articles, and make bold (ideological?) claims about the potential future implications of the protocol. I don't have ill will against the submitter or the author, they're just the easiest and starkest examples, I wish them luck with this herculean task.

I don't want to impose my opinion as correct opinion, quite the opposite, I want to leave others to experiment and have fun, I want these stories to be on here.

I'm happy that there's so much interest in the protocol, because it _could_ work out if enough people build on top of it to make sure it's actually an open protocol and not just the Bluesky and friends protocol.

But until the dust settles, I wish I could just tune it out on here because these stories are really frustrating to me as a reader, and I don't know how I can hide them (compared to things like vibecoding / ai).

I hope my sob story isn't too disruptive, I don't think I've seen this kind of text written on here before.
